awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Group-Based Cloud Computing for STEM Education Project
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by designing, developing, implementing, and studying a socio-technological system for group-centered STEM teaching and learning consistent with a nationally recognized pre-service program. The project will use results from more than 30 years of research to demonstrate how network supported, group-based learning grounded in principles of Generative Design can improve learning for all learners, across racial/ethnic backgrounds. The project will also offer detailed analyses of activity designs and implementation strategies that will help pre-service teachers to develop more fully participatory and socially-supported approaches to classroom learning, using authentic STEM practices in group-centered learning environments. This work will be particularly important to advancing knowledge in the field for pre-service teacher preparation, since few pre-service programs use this approach in preparing teachers for today?s classrooms.  Through a focus on the initial implementation of twelve model activities taught by pre-service teachers in K-12 classrooms nationwide, this study will also provide concrete and quantitative evidence that group-based learning is both appealing to early-career and induction-years teachers, and that it is feasible to implement in real classrooms.

The project takes a design-based research approach to creating and studying technologies and materials that support generative teaching and learning in STEM.  Sites associated with a nationally recognized and expanding approach to STEM teacher preparation and certification will serve as incubators and testbeds for the project?s innovation and development efforts.  Computational thinking, including agent-based modeling, and simulation across STEM domains as well as geo-spatial reasoning about personally meaningful learner-collected data will provides an important scientific foundation for the project.  This will be achieved by developing a highly-interactive and group-optimized, browser- and cloud-based, device-independent and open-source architecture and by integrating and extending leading computational tools including the NSF-funded NetLogo Web agent-based modeling language and environment. The project will also achieve this outcome by publishing its technology-mediated activities and materials in the public domain and by capturing extensive qualitative and quantitative data on the intensity and nature of use of these technologies and materials. Collectively, the project will foster the growth of educational infrastructures to enable the dissemination and effective adoption of generative teaching and learning in STEM.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the Group-Based Cloud Computing project (GBCC) is to expand on the possible classroom activities available in the NetLogo software family. NetLogo Desktop, the most widely used agent-based modeling (ABM) software, is used to model scientific phenomena in both classroom and professional settings. It has hundreds of thousands of active users. In educational settings, it is used to structure science inquiry activities that involve modeling and simulation. In this project, we have created much improved infrastructure for utilizing the power of NetLogo in collaborative classroom inquiry activities.

Technologically speaking our practical goals were 1) to greatly enhance the usability and power of the NetLogo Web software, lowering the threshold of entry and increasing the ceiling to be comparable to the NetLogo Desktop software, 2) to create a server infrastructure that would enable teacher and students to run and participate in agent-based modeling classroom activities, 3) Create a web-based version of the HubNet participatory simulation architecture to enable web-based participatory simulations. HubNet Web was completely redesigned to lower the threshold and increase the ceiling of possible participatory simulation activities.

 

We describe our progress in each of the 3 below.

 1)    The NetLogo Web software

We greatly improved usability of NetLogo Web.  These included a significant improvement in error reporting, performance gains and aligning NetLogo Web to NetLogo desktop. We greatly increased the range of model visualizations and enhanced the plotting functions. We are now seeing significant increases in uses of NetLogo Web rivaling the number of users of the Desktop software, most especially so in educational settings.

 

2)    A server infrastructure for classroom collaborative ABM activities

The project has contributed substantial innovations to group-based activities in ABM suited to classroom settings. By adding extensions to NetLogo Web,  we enabled flexible and reliable authoring and delivery of activities in a browser. 

 

GbCC is inherently open-ended and generative.  The following listing indicates the range of classroom activities and explorations it has enabled.

 

Enhanced PartSims. Because GbCC enables flexible messaging, it is possible to expand the distribution of views and controls between students and the teacher.  E.g., individuals or groups can embody mathematical objects, such as contributions from the class identifying a mathematical Locus of Points.

 

Living Class Quilt. With very small modifications to almost any NetLogo model from the library, a classroom group can explore the parameter space of the model, publishing either a VIEW a GRAPH or a result. These show up in the class Gallery. The complete run can be published along with this summary artifact, and anyone in the class, can ‘browse’ the gallery, ‘adopt’ a student’s work, explore it, and either remix or return to their own.

 

Markup, Replay, and Publish. We enabled replay and ‘sharing’ of model runs. Students can also ‘mark up’ the run by identifying moments as worthy of notice. The aggregate markups can be displayed as a heat map of interest, which can drive discussion about the hotspots. 

 

State Sharing and analysis. Students generate questions that need collective exploration of a variable space. Exploring this space requires a large number of runs. Students conduct runs, interpret results, and post their data to the gallery. They then retrieve each others’ states to replicate experiments and interpret/verify/contest results.

 

3)    HubNet Web

HubNet Web is a web-based implementation of the HubNet multi-user computer modeling software. Where standard HubNet is built on top of the NetLogo desktop application, HubNet Web is web-based. The biggest advantages of re-implementing these features to run on the web are (a) no installation is needed to launch the activities, (b) instructions for how to connect to an activity can be made very simple and (c) browser-based activities can run on a much greater range of devices (d) the browser-based version has no difficulties with connecting users over the internet. In short, basing HubNet Web on modern web technologies allows for a lower barrier to entry for using HubNet, provides a simpler user experience for finding and connecting to HubNet activities, and gives many devices access to HubNet that would otherwise be unable to participate.

Although we made great progress towards a full HubNet Web application, we weren’t able to complete the app in the project period. We have done extensive testing of the “alpha” version and expect to release the full application to the public in 2022.

One important change that we made to the design of HubNet was to simplify authoring activities. We introduced a graphical authoring tool  enabling removing all HubNet primitives from the NetLogo language.

Currently, 28 of the 39 standard non-web-based HubNet activities run in HubNet Web.

 

Student USe

Using combinations of these technologies, classroom groups from a wide range of subject areas (science, math, social studies), ages (grades 5-12)and technology platforms were able to use the GBCC software to engage in collectively creating and analyzing agent-based models.
